metadata.title: How to Connect to an EMR Cluster

content:
n EMR Cluster, please follow these steps:

1. Obtain Permission: First, you need to get access authorization for the IP address 10.244.30.140 from the Alpha team.
2. Initial Connection: Once you have the necessary permissions, establish a Secure Shell (SSH) connection. Use the following example command: ssh yasinu@10.244.30.140
3. Switch to Airflow User: After successfully connecting, switch to the airflow user by entering the command: sudo su - airflow
4. Connect to the Primary Node of the Running EMR Cluster: Ensure you have a running cluster on EMR. Then, connect to the primary node using SSH as indicated in the provided screenshot.
5. Copy the Necessary Part: You should copy the part that starts with 'hadoop' from the instructions or the screenshot.
6. Execute the SSH Command: Finally, execute the following SSH command to connect to the EMR Cluster:  This command will log you into the EMR Cluster.ssh -i ~/.ssh/airflow_emr_euwest1 hadoop@ip-10-244-31-214.eu-west-1.compute.internal

metadata.title: How to Connect to an EMR Cluster

content:
the EMR Cluster.ssh -i ~/.ssh/airflow_emr_euwest1 hadoop@ip-10-244-31-214.eu-west-1.compute.internal

Ensure you follow these steps carefully to establish a successful connection to the EMR Cluster.

metadata.title: How to Connect to an EMR Cluster

content:
### transfer_product_agg_level_matching

`invent-apparelgroupgreen-datastore/operation/transfer_product_agg_level_matching` has 1516509 count.

Schema of table:

```yaml
  transfer_product_agg_level_matching:
    schema:
      product_agg_level:
        type: string
        alias: ProductAggLevel
      product_id:
        type: string
        alias: ProductId
```

As you can see, we have 'product_id', and since 'maps-xs' has a limited number of products, I filtered them to match the existing products in 'maps-xs'. In the end, we are left with 100.

```py
df_transfer_product_agg_level_matching = df_transfer_product_agg_level_matching.join(df_maps_xs_products, "product_id", "inner")
df_transfer_product_agg_level_matching = df_transfer_product_agg_level_matching.select("product_agg_level", "product_id")
```

### transfer_store_agg_level_matching

metadata.title: Transfer Integration Test Data Preparation

content:
_level_matching.select("product_agg_level", "product_id")
```

### transfer_store_agg_level_matching

`invent-apparelgroupgreen-datastore/operation/transfer_store_agg_level_matching` has 1450 data. and has `store_id` and `store_agg_level` columns. We know that `maps-xs` has limited stores; for this reason, I filtered it with existing stores in `maps-xs`. At the end we have 17.

```py
df_transfer_store_agg_level_matching = df_transfer_store_agg_level_matching.join(df_maps_xs_stores, "store_id", "inner")
df_transfer_store_agg_level_matching = df_transfer_store_agg_level_matching.select("store_id", "store_agg_level")
```

### store_transfer_decisions

metadata.title: Transfer Integration Test Data Preparation

content:
fer_store_agg_level_matching.select("store_id", "store_agg_level")
```

### store_transfer_decisions

`invent-apparelgroupgreen-datastore/operation/store_transfer_decisions` has data on it and it has `1185250`rows. But the thing is that this table consists  multiple columns: `destination_type`, `delivery_date`, `quantity`, `execution_date`, `destination_id`, `product_id`, `approved_quantity`, `source_type`, `source_id`, `transferred_quantity`, `transfer_run_id`. When I filter it with source_id, destination_id, product_id with `maps-xs` data I am getting zero count of data. For this reason, I created my own fake data. In this existing data I randomly give source_id, destination_id and product_id from `maps-xs`.

```py
# Extract store_ids and product_ids
store_ids = df_maps_xs_stores.select("store_id").distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x: x).collect()
product_ids = df_maps_xs_products.select("product_id").distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x: x).collect()

metadata.title: Transfer Integration Test Data Preparation

content:
product_ids = df_maps_xs_products.select("product_id").distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x: x).collect()

# UDF to generate random store ID different from the given store ID
def random_store_id(exclude_id):
    choice = random.choice([id for id in store_ids if id != exclude_id])
    return choice

random_store_id_udf = udf(random_store_id, IntegerType())

# UDF for random product_id
random_product_id_udf = udf(lambda: random.choice(product_ids), IntegerType())

# Load your df_store_transfer_decisions DataFrame
# Replace the below line with your actual DataFrame loading logic

# Generate fake data
df_fake = df_store_transfer_decisions.withColumn("source_id", random_store_id_udf("destination_id")) \
                                     .withColumn("destination_id", random_store_id_udf("source_id")) \
                                     .withColumn("product_id", random_product_id_udf())

# Replicate the DataFrame to create 20 rows
df_fake = df_fake.limit(20)

metadata.title: Transfer Integration Test Data Preparation

content:

# Replicate the DataFrame to create 20 rows
df_fake = df_fake.limit(20)

# Show the result
df_fake.show()
```

Now I have 100 data for this table.

### store_distances

In ApparelGroup db we don‚Äôt have store_distances data. For this reason I created one row fake data with random store_id.

```py
data = [(121, 0, 166, 0, 3, "km")]
columns = ["source_id", "source_type", "destination_id", "destination_type", "distance", "uom"]
df_store_distances = spark.createDataFrame(data, columns)
```

### blocked_store

In ApparelgroupGreen we don‚Äôt have sample dataset for this table. For this reason, I randomly selected a store which id is 3 (which also exists in maps-xs).

```py
data = [(23, random_store, 0)]
columns = ["solution_id", "location_id", "location_type"]
df_blocked_stores = spark.createDataFrame(data, columns)
```

| transfer_etl | store_transfer_decisions | 1.16 |

| transfer_etl | price_history | 2.31 |
| transfer_etl | cost_history | 2.03 |
| transfer_etl | product_store_seasonality | 1.12 |
